author: @Mvshotz

comment:
Whether or not the tool responds with clarifying questions or recognizes flaws in question, is fundamental to what we consider intelligence. Does it do that? I've never used it. 
What would happen if two different people asked it identical questions at the same time, would it produce a different result? It's ability to empathize or evaluate its audience at the time seems also fundamental to human intelligence.
Can it process non English language content without the bottle neck of translating it to English? How the tool operates within a cultural or geographical context seems important, too. 
At what point will we combine this artificial brain with a sensory system that is devoid of neurological and emotional connections to that brain? Imagine eyes that can see in all spectrums of light, and hear the extreme frequencies of sound waves? Oh and by the way it can actively analyze those two things and create a third combined sensory measurement. That factor compounds again when it can feel via sound pressure levels and taste or smell with static electricity levels of precision. Will it aggregate these inputs to manufacture emotions, maybe averaging that data with the sample data's average emotional reaction to similar events?  
I'm just afraid that we will exhaust resources with this before it teaches us how to save those resources. We will bite our human experience into tiny pieces attempting to load every granular detail of our realities into this artificial intelligence.   I would argue that a spiritual super power or a surge of love and empathy on this world, would do a lot more than the technological advancements of this tool.
